Philip and I are working primarily in game domains,
and one of the things I've been thinking a lot about
lately is artificial ecology.  I've had some
interesting discussions with Ken about this, but I
thought I'd open it up to the group as well, and see
if anyone had any thoughts on it.

I really like some of the work Sean Luke has done:

http://cs.gmu.edu/~sean/papers/

His and Liviu Panait's paper "A Comparison of Two
Competitive Fitness Functions" really got me thinking
about the best way to evaluate the fitness of
competing individuals.

He compares different approaches to pairing which
individuals compete directly with which, in various
domains.

There's the K-Random Opponents approach, in which each
individual plays a random number of other individuals
in the population (e.g. In a population of 100
individuals, each individual might play 5 random
opponents, then all individuals' fitnesses are ranked
based on their performance).  The extremes of this
general approach are Round Robin, in which each
individual plays every other individual in the
population, and Random Pairing, in which each
individual only plays one other random individual per
generation.

They compared this approach to a Single-Elimination
Tournament approach, and found that SET performs
reasonably well by comparison, depending on the
noisiness of the domain.

Unfortunately, they only delve into the dynamics of
one-population competitive coevolution.  I was hoping
to find many more permutations on various competitive
coevolutionary strategies, but I haven't seen too
many.

Rosin and Belew have done some interesting work as
well, but I've griped to Ken about their conceptual
approach.

They employ two-population competitive coevolution,
but each generation, the two populations take turns
being designated the "host population" and the
"parasite population", even though logically they're
competing within the same domain (which biological
hosts and parasites are not).

It seems to me that the distinction between
interspecies (foxes and rabbits) competition and
intraspecies competition (rabbits and other rabbits)
is a crucial one.  The mathematical dynamics are
completely different, aren't they?  

Even at the most basic level, if F is the number of
individuals in the fox population and R is the number
of individuals in the rabbit population, then if R=0,
F will eventually dwindle to 0.  That is, a population
of rabbits can survive without foxes, but not vice
versa.  However, when you're talking about two
populations of rabbits, the existence of one isn't
contingent on the existence of the other.  In fact, if
either population is eradicated, most likely the other
will flourish.

Basically, I believe there's a fundamental difference
in populations competing for the same resource, and in
situations where one of the populations *is* the
resource for the other.

But it's not just a matter of semantics.  I think
there are underlying inefficiencies in the way Rosin
and Belew evaluate individuals each generation (i.e.,
an individual's fitness as a "parasite" is never
evaluated).

Anyway, Rosin and Belew's research has inspired me to
think a lot about this subject as well, and as I've
said, Ken and I have hashed some of this stuff out
too. :)

But I was wondering if anyone else had directly worked
with competitive coevolutionary paradigms or had any
thoughts about constructive approaches to the problem.

Derek
